tasks.task: Understanding different types of sprinklers commonly used in residential landscapes.
subtasks: Recognizing rotors as a type of sprinkler that rotates water in partial or full circles.
Identifying pop-up heights for rotors (4-inch, 6, and 12-inch) and their typical uses (grass lawns or other ground covers).
Understanding shrub rotors and their placement in flower beds or behind larger plants where tripping hazards exist.
Recognizing spray heads versus nozzles, their pop-up heights (2, 4, 6, 12-inch), and their common use in flower beds.
Understanding the benefits of rotary nozzles over sprays for water efficiency and lesser water pressure requirements (optimal 40-45 psi).
Learning about impacts, an old-fashioned type of rotor, and their uses in situations with a steady water source like ponds or wells, suitable for agriculture and dust control.
Identifying flood bubblers for creating small puddles in specific areas like watering basins for new trees or dusty areas.
Considering the use of hose-end sprinklers for spot watering without installation and their compatibility with hose-end timers.
Understanding the role of drip systems in water conservation and their connection to regular sprinkler systems.
Recognizing specialty sprinklers like upside-down hanging systems for greenhouses.
